APPLICATIONS FOR ENTRY INTO COLONY
(Furnishing of grounds for refusals)


    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he is aware that no grounds for refusals are given by the Controller of Immigration to sponsors of applicants for entry into the Colony; and if he will direct the Controller of Immigration to furnish grounds in future.

    Mr Braga: The Controller of Immigration is empowered to refuse any application for an entry permit if he is satisfied that the applicant is a prohibited immigrant. Where he has refused entry to any person he shall if so requested by such person inform him of the class of prohibited immigrant of which in the opinion of the Controller he is a member - and this has always been complied with.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, is the Minister aware that a sponsor has to wait sometimes three years for the result of his application and that after the result has been given no reason for the refusal is stated?

    Mr Braga: I am not aware of that.

NEWLY REGISTERED SINGAPORE CITIZENS
(Waiving of visa fees)


    5. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether the Government will consider waiving the visa fees charged by the Immigration Department in respect of newly registered Singapore citizens applying for travel documents.

Column: 326



    Mr Braga: No, Sir. Until the amendment to the British Nationality Act of 1948 is made which will give Singapore citizenship international status, visas are required for newly registered Singapore citizens. ALLEGED ILL-TREATMENT OF TAN HONG PIEW IN REMAND PRISON


    8. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary whether he has received a copy of a letter from the General Secretary of the Singapore Peasants' Union regarding the alleged ill-treatment in the Remand Prison of Tan Hong Piew, detained under the Banishment Ordinance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

    Mr David: Yes, Sir, I have received a copy of the letter in question and in view of the wide circulation it has been given by the Union, I welcome the opportunity to make a statement.

    It is alleged in the letter dated 8th May that since his arrest on 30th April this blind man had been locked in a cell by himself for the night at 4 p.m. each day and that he had been denied any solid food.

    The facts are that on his committal to the Remand Prison on 30th April, this man was immediately admitted to a ward in the Prison hospital. This ward contained some 15 other patients and is provided with modern latrine and washing facilities in an adjoining alcove. Hospital orderlies are on duty night and day to attend to the needs of the patients and there is a resident medical officer close at hand. On admission to the hospital, this man was found to be suffering from pyelitis and on the doctors orders he has been given three extra meals a day in addition to the normal diet. This extra food includes two eggs a day.

REGISTRATION OF HINDU MARRIAGES
(Introduction of legislation)


    9. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary, with reference to the Report of the Committee on Hindu Marriage Registration (Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 37 of 1957), whether, and when, the Government will introduce legislation for the registration of Hindu marriages.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, can the Chief Secretary tell us why the Government does not propose to introduce such legislation?

    Mr David: Sir, this is a matter in which we consider it necessary to keep in line with the Federation Government and I understand that they have recently appointed a committee to examine the necessity for enacting legislation of this kind.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, is the Government going to wait until the findings of that Committee of the Federation Government are published?

EXCHANGE CONTROL ORDINANCE


    10. Mr R. Jumabhoy asked the Financial Secretary, in view of the comments made on a recent case heard in the High Court under section 9 (1) of the Exchange Control Ordinance (Cap. 216), whether he will consider introducing amending legislation or take any other steps to exclude payments of moneys in which the Colony has no interest at all from the scope of the said section 9 (1).

Column: 329



    Mr T. M. Hart: No, Sir, It is still considered essential as an effective check on evasion that the existing provision should be retained. It will be appreciated that section 9 of the Ordinance does not impose an absolute prohibition on acts preparatory to the making of payments outside the Colony for the credit of persons resident outside the scheduled territories. It only makes such an act an offence if the permission of the Controller is not obtained but such permission is readily given if the Controller is satisfied that there will not be a loss of foreign exchange.

EXCHANGE CONTROL ORDINANCE


    11. Mr R. Jumabhoy asked the Financial Secretary how many applications have been made to the Controller of Foreign Exchange for permission to do any of the acts referred to in section 9 (1) of the Exchange Control Ordinance (Cap. 216) since the commencement of the Ordinance up to a latest convenient date; in how many cases has permission been granted; and whether he will state what is the policy and what are the principles adopted in the granting or refusal of such permission.

    Mr Hart: Sir, I regret that it has not been considered practicable, having regard to the other commitments of the limited staff of the Controller's office, to search through the 11,000 files which have been opened during the past four years to obtain the information requested. The number of applications of the kind to which the hon. Member refers has amounted to many hundreds. It can safely be said that almost all the applications covered transactions which did not involve foreign currency loss under any section of the Ordinance and in such cases the applications were approved.

    The basis on which an application is judged is whether or not, in all the circumstances involved, the transaction will entail a direct loss of foreign currency or an indirect loss by omitting to bring to the scheduled territories

Column: 330

foreign currency earned overseas. Where on complete disclosure of all the details of a transaction the Controller is satisfied that there would be no direct or indirect loss of foreign exchange, the application is granted.

VETERINARY DEPARTMENT OF CITY COUNCIL
(Taking over by Government)


    14. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether, and when, the Government will take over the Veterinary Department of the City Council.

Column: 331

POLICE FORCE BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.21 a.m.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr E. B. David): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency's consent to proceed with this Bill.

    I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, as explained in the statement at the end of the Bill, this is primarily a consolidating measure. At present, the Police Force is administered and organised in accordance with the provisions of the Police Force Ordinance, 1941, read together with the Singapore Police Force Ordinance, 1949, and it is clearly time that we had a single up-to-date statute regulating the Force. This Bill, Sir, is based not only on the 1941 and 1949 Ordinances but also borrows

Column: 335

or adapts certain provisions from the Federation of Malaya Police Ordinance, 1952. Details are set out in the comparative table at the end of the Bill.

    The main innovation in the Bill is in clause 21 which provides for the establishment of one or more Police associations to be operated and administered in accordance with Police regulations. It is intended that these associations should form the medium through which members of the Force can bring to notice any grievances regarding their pay or conditions of service and can seek satisfactory remedies through appropriate forms of negotiating machinery. Since the Police is a disciplined Force, this machinery cannot appropriately take the ordinary form of a trade union with the right to strike in support of demands. The provision of associations on these lines accords with the practice in force both in the Federation of Malaya and in the United Kingdom.

    Since this Bill was published, Sir, certain representations have been made by the inspectorate in regard to the provisions of clause 20 and clause 28 of the Bill which provide for the discharge or dismissal of inspectors. These representations can properly be considered at the Committee stage of the Bill when those clauses are considered and it is my intention to move that the Bill should be committed to a Select Committee.

    Representations have also been received regarding the period of time allowed for appeal under clauses 27 and 28 of the Bill and it will be my intention at the Committee stage to move that the ten days provided in the Bill should be changed to 30 days.

    Sir, there are certain other amendments to the Bill to be moved at the Committee stage of which I have given notice but these are mostly of a formal nature and do not affect the substantive provisions of the Bill. The only one on which I would like to comment at this stage is clause 51 of the Bill which deals with the administration of intestate estates. As the clause is at present drafted, it is doubtful whether the

Column: 336

Deputy Commissioner will have powers to deal with money as well as with goods and chattels. To clarify the position, it is proposed to substitute the expression "movable property" for "goods and chattels" and to redraft the clause accordingly.

    Sir, I do not think I need say any more at this stage and I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.

    Committed to a Select Committee consisting of Mr Speaker as Chairman and five Members to be nominated by the Committee of Selection. (Mr David).

PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENTS BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.26 a.m.

    Mr David: Sir, I have His Excellency's consent to proceed with this Bill.

    The Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary (Mr M. P. D. Nair): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Committee on Local Government appointed in July 1955 recommended amongst other things that the safety and amenity aspects of the control of places of public entertainment, both temporary and permanent, should be administered by the local authorities, the moral aspect by the police and the welfare aspect by the Social Welfare Department. The Government agreed with these recommendations in the White Paper on Government policy relating to local government.

    The Local Government Bill, 1957, which has been passed by the Legislative Assembly, makes enabling provision for local authorities to make bylaws now for the control, regulation and supervision by registration, licensing or otherwise of places used for real performances, theatres, wayangs, concerts and other public exhibitions and enter tainments.

    A considerable part of the Theatres Ordinance (Cap. 229) which assigned some of this responsibility to the police consequently becomes obsolete and fit

Column: 337

for repeal. In addition, other provisions of the same Ordinance have become out of date through changes in the social life of the community since it was enacted in 1909. It is timely therefore to repeal the whole of the Theatres Ordinance and to replace it by a new Ordinance directed to the regulation of public entertainments in general. This Bill has accordingly been framed so as to require that the Licensing Authority constituted under it should have regard primarily to the nature of public entertainments for which licences are sought; while also concerned that these are held only in places suitable to their nature, the Licensing Authority is permitted to presume the suitability of buildings and other premises to the extent to which this has been certified by a local government authority.

    This Bill, Sir, which repeals the present Theatres Ordinance and the Billiards Ordinance which is equally out of date and will no longer be necessary if this Bill is enacted, is based on the following considerations and requirements: the interest of the State in controlling entertainments to which the public has access is fourfold - to preserve peace and good order: to prevent moral, social and political degeneracy: to prevent physical injury and suffering whether to performers or to audiences: to secure revenue sufficient at least to offset the expense of control; the definition of "public entertainment" which should be as clear as possible and comprehensive enough to take account of the much greater range of popular amusements available nowadays so that loopholes in the system of control could be prevented as much as possible; the statutory exemptions of some kinds of public entertainment because their sponsorship and circumstances adequately guarantee the State's interest being safeguarded; the exemption from control either wholly or in part of other kinds of "public entertainment" the nature of which cannot readily be perverted to ends contrary to the State's interest; the introduction of a system of licensing of "public entertainment" which provides for the identification of all persons on whom lies the onus of compliance with the

Column: 338

conditions of licences; the declaration in advance of the precise nature of the entertainment; approval of the place in which it is intended to provide entertainment; the refusal and cancellation of licences; the suspension of licences on reasonable suspicion that they will be abused or will result in breaches of the peace or injury or suffering to animals or performers or members of the audience; recourse to expert opinion in cases of doubt whether an entertainment should be licensed or not; the collection of fees.

    Sir, it is the intention of the Government that after the Second Reading of this important Bill, it should be committed to a Select Committee. I do not propose therefore to go into great detail at this juncture. Hon. Members will also have read the explanatory statement at the end of the Bill. I would like however to dwell at this stage on some of the more important clauses and implications of this Bill.

    The definition of "public entertainment" under the 14 headings is intended to be absolutely comprehensive of all existing and all probable forms of public entertainment, without any implication as to the inherent desirability or otherwise of the particular types of public entertainment mentioned. The final part of the definition excludes absolutely from the operation of the Ordinance certain categories of public entertainment associated with the State, official, religious, business and political occasions, it is considered not only necessary for the avoidance of embarrassment and administrative congestion, but also essential to preserve freedom of association for those categories to be statutorily exempted from the application of this Bill. As I have already indicated above, it is contemplated that other exemptions will also be granted and clause 15 of the Bill gives the Minister unfettered discretion to make orders for this purpose.

    Hon. Members will wish to be made aware of the provisions of clause 10 (2) of the Bill which will enable the Licensing Officer to prohibit at his discretion the admission of children under the age of sixteen years to the licensed public

Column: 339

entertainment. There is ample occasion in Singapore today for the use of every available means of protecting the younger generation from bad influence in the field of public entertainment. The onus of responsibility for seeing that this prohibition is carried out will fall on the licensee of the public entertainment. This would apply even to cinemas. If this Bill is passed, classification of films as suitable or unsuitable for children to see could be made under the Cinematograph Films Ordinance. The Licensing Officer under this Bill could then impose on the licensees of cinemas that one of the conditions of a licence should be that no children under the age of sixteen years should be admitted to see films classified as unsuitable for children by the Film Censor. This provision, Sir, is a very important one and it is my intention to ask the Select Committee to examine the implications of this provision in particular.

    Clauses 13 and 14 deal, as the explanatory statement shows, with the refusal, cancellation and suspension of licences. The clauses are straightforward and are in keeping with the main considerations and requirements on which, as I stated earlier, the Bill is based.

    Clause 19 is for the resolution of doubt whether any entertainment was "public" or not. Attempts to rebut changes under the Bill on the grounds that entertainments were not "public" must be anticipated. In placing the onus of proof on the person alleging that the entertainment is not "public", regard has been given to the circumstance that such doubt will be material only when an offence under the Ordinance has prima facie been committed, and to the extensive exemptions allowed for statutorily and expected to be conferred by the Minister under the Bill.

    Sir, another important clause is clause 22 which introduces a provision long sought by the Licensing Authority under the Theatres Ordinance to allow effective recourse to the best available expert advice in determining whether a particular public entertainment, especially if

Column: 340

of the nature of a professional sporting contest, for example, boxing or wrestling contests, should be licensed or not. The clause provides that "it shall be sufficient reason for refusing" to license such an entertainment if the expert advice given is that it should be refused but final discretion is given to the Licensing Officer whether he wishes to act in accordance with the advice he has received.

    Sir, as I have indicated earlier, I do not propose to go into matters of detail which could of course be dealt with in the ordinary way in Committee but it is the Government's intention after its Second Reading to have the Bill committed to a Select Committee. I am confident, Sir, that the purpose of this Bill and the principles on which it is based will commend itself to hon. Members and that they will give it its Second Reading.

    Question proposed.
